Award.AwardTitle: Econometrics of Asymmetric Information Models with Applications to Nonlinear Pricing, Insurance and Compensation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the nineties, the empirical analysis of auctions has been an active research area to which the PIs contributed with the support of previous NSF grants. Auctions are mechanisms in which buyers compete given their private willingness to pay for an object. The seller's problem is to design auction rules that secure the maximum return. Auctions are asymmetric information models. The PIs propose to analyze new data modeled similarly. As in their previous work, they begin with an economic model, study thoroughly the mapping between it and the data as well as develop quantitative methods drawing from empirical processes, kernel estimation and characteristic functions.
First, price discounts (nonlinear pricing) to big buyers are studied. The PIs collect new data on yellow page advertising and cellular phone services. For the latter, they consider a firm proposing two products, namely, voice and SMS. They also address the problem of testing adverse selection by deriving the model restrictions on observables. Second, the research project analyzes insurance in which insurers are heterogeneous in both risk and in attitudes toward risk. Moreover, the PIs consider a finite number of contracts. Both lead to pooling at equilibrium, which represents new challenges. They assess deviations from contract optimality and resulting losses for the insurer. Policy questions are addressed with new data on automobile insurance. Third, this project studies executive compensation and develops models incorporating moral hazard and (i) competition among firms to attract managers and (ii) heterogeneous managers in risk attitudes; utilizing data from S&P ExecuComp.
This project further advances the structural analysis of asymmetric information models while addressing fundamental questions. Several new data sets on yellow page advertising, mobile phone service and automobile insurance are collected and will be available to the research community. The methods developed by the PIs will be used by empirical researchers from industrial organization but also from other fields such as health, labor and corporate finance. The results of this project will also assist public institutions in better understanding the impact of regulatory policies on the insurance industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project develops new methodologies to analyze  nonlinear pricing and insurance data  under incomplete information.

Seven papers  are  already published/forthcoming in refereed journals or under review.  Four more papers are close to submission.

Regarding  nonlinear pricing, we consider the canonical model when firms face heterogenous consumers. We study the identification and estimation of the  model primitives, i.e.  consumers' utility, their tastes distribution  and the firm's cost. We show that they are uniquely recovered from observed consumptions when the  firm's tariff is known. We characterize the model restrictions on observables. We propose a   nonparametric quantile-based estimator for the model primitives. Our estimator converges at the parametric rate and hence is less demanding in  sample size. We  consider an unknown tariff with product unobserved heterogeneity and  extend our identification and  estimation results.  A Monte Carlo study  analyzes the robustness of our methodology to  menus of two-part tariffs. The analysis of cellular service data assesses  the performance of   alternative pricing strategies. Though the loss in firm's profit is small, they exclude more consumers with low taste consumers being most hurt. Our method extends to network effects,multiproduct firm, bundling, product differentiation and competition. Beyond nonlinear pricing, our methodology is useful to analyze pricing data with regulated firms and contract data under environmental regulation, retailing and labor where incomplete information plays a key role.

Regarding  insurance,  we consider insurance models where insurees have private information in both risk and risk aversion. While considering constant absolute risk aversion,   the model primitives are the damage distribution and  the joint distribution of risk and risk aversion. We consider  a finite number of coverages offered by the insurer and the potential truncation of the damage distribution at the deductible.  The number of accidents plays a key role in recovering the model primitives. The joint distribution of risk and risk aversion is identified under a support assumption and an exclusion restriction. Our identification results hold for any competitive environment making our results very general for the analysis of insurance data. We discuss how to extend our results to health insurance.

 We also study the rationalization and identification of discrete games where players have correlated private information   such as in global games, network and social interactions. The approach is fully nonparametric. Given a monotone pure Bayesian Nash equilibrium,   we consider  (i) additive separability of private information in the payoffs, (ii) exogeneity of the payoff shifters relative to private information, and (iii) mutual independence of private information conditional on the payoff shifters.We  study the nonparametric identification of the payoff functions and type distribution under exclusion restrictions and rank conditions. We also characterize all the  model restrictions and discuss possible estimation and testing procedures.

 

We  also study   individual treatment effects in a nonseparable model with a binary endogenous regressor. The outcome variable may be continuous, discrete or a mixture of both, while the instrumental variable takes on binary values. We distinguish the case where the model includes or not a selection equation for the latter. When there is a selection equation, we establish point identification of the structural function.  The key  is the identification of a so-called `counterfactual mapping' that links each outcome with its counterfactual. This identifies every individual treatment effect. Second, we generalize  identification  when there is no selection equation. Third, we characterize all the testable model restrictions in both cases.  We generalize our results to censored or binary outcome variable. We  develop an estimation procedure for the triangular model with binary-valued endogenous treatments. We first estimate the counterfactual outcome and the individual treatment effect for every individual in the sample. Second, we estimate the density of the individual treatment effects in the population. Our estimation procedure does not suffer from the ill-posed inverse problem encountered previously. We derive asymptotic properties  and conduct a Monte Carlo study. We assess empirically the effects of 401(k) retirement programs on savings. Overall, the effect is positive though a small proportion of individuals experience a negative effect.

We also extended our previous work on auctions by  studying how uncertainty about realized costs affects bidding in construction projects. We develop a  model with heterogenous risk averse bidders, ex post cost uncertainty and potential  cost asymmetry. Asymmetry in risk aversion leads to compatibility conditions within the same auction. In addition, if the number of bidders exogenous, the model leads to additional compatibility conditions across auctions. Both conditions help to identify the model primitives which are the bidders' utility functions and the shock distribution. We consider a hyperbolic utility function and a scaled recentered Beta distribution. The estimator relies on the compabitibility conditions. We analyze construction procurement data. The empirical results show that more experienced bidders are  risk neutral while less experienced bidders display decreasing absolute risk aversion. Their risk premium represents a significant amount of their bids. Our empirical results  assess a negligible asymmetry in costs.
